quest_name: Mission? Well, look straight ahead. Now give me a

history.location_text:
Mission? Well, look straight ahead. Now give me a jump... higher! Even higher! One step forward. Squat down, stand up straight. One jump forward, one jump back - don't turn! Stand up, stop wincing and nursing your tail base... Not bad at all.

I think you are the one we need, Ranger. Our scholars invented a unique device, which was sent to the Institute of Inventions and Innovations on planet Bonnasis for patenting. Unfortunately, we didn't have time to test it thoroughly so now we can't complete the application for the patent. There is only one test remaining - field-testing - but it is the most important one. We have already rented a test lab in the Institute and invited stuntmen but they failed to complete the testing.

As a ranger, you must be perfectly trained. We will even pay you twice as much as a stuntman gets - it makes 65535 cr, if you go to planet Bonnasis (system Procyon) and manage to test the device. But keep in mind that the patent submission is due to expire, so you must do all the testing by 6 February 3000.
history.reasoning: (auto-selected single choice)

history.location_text:
You took an aerocab that brought you to the Inventions and Innovations. It was near the Academy of Anthropological and Amorphous Anomalies. You entered and asked which way you should go.

A gloomy assistant accompanied you along the tortuous corridors. You met a Maloq with a stunt man's badge hopping with his crutches, then they carried by a litter with an unconscious man - your colleague. A gaal in a wheelchair saw where you were going. Then he approached you, gave you a sympathising look, and mentioned quietly: "Heh, he's so young", - after that he wheeled away.

The assistant brought you to the "Test laboratory No 13" and kindly opened the door.
- Ranger? - a fae stood up to meet you. - Nice to meet you, I'm professor Hab, I manage the testing of the device and collect all the information necessary for the patent application preparation. Have a sit.
You sat obediently on the offered chair.
- Stand up, now sit down again. Bounce on your toes. Higher. Still higher! Now hold your breath. Hold your left ear with your right hand and the right ear with your left hand... Not mine!!!
He measured your pulse and nodded with satisfaction.
- Excellent. Pulse, co-ordination, reflexes  - you are in perfect shape and this is very important for the "Jumper"'s testing. By the way, you may breathe.

You exhaled with relief:
choices: What exactly am I supposed to do?
history.reasoning: (auto-selected single choice)

history.location_text:
- You must test the jumping backpack - "Jumper". We rented a pavilion for the testing and tossed a facility. Your task is to go through the labyrinth made of hanging platforms jumping from one platform to another using the "Jumper". The labyrinth consists of the starting and finishing points and five rows of platforms between them.  Your task is to make a number of jumps to get from the starting point through the labyrinth to the finishing point . And you can jump only within the row you are at or onto the platforms of the next row.

Jumps require power consumption, which is measured in ergo and depends on the length of the jump. You will have two batteries  20 ergo each. One battery is active, and the other is spare. Our technicians promise that would be enough.

There are additional devices somewhere on the platforms, which allow you to replace the active battery, top it up or even get back to the starting point where you can charge the both batteries and start the testing from the very beginning. If you want to cancel the testing and, accordingly, abandon your fee, you can use the emergency return button.
choices: Take me to the scaffold... I mean, to the testing facility. I agree to stretch my legs a little bit... Lord forbid, of course!
Please give me more details about the labyrinth's configuration and explain how I can go through it.
What is the power consumption during jumping?
You said something about additional devices in the labyrinth...
Please tell me once again -what is my task?
Can you tell me more about the "Jumper"? What's the hang of this device?
What are your guarantees? Have you experienced any accidents?
Oh, no - the disability pension is not big enough to affect grasshopper.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I need to familiarize myself with the internal mechanics of the "Jumper" and the layout of the labyrinth before starting. My previous failure was a direct result of energy mismanagement, arriving at the final row with only 3 ergo. To prevent this, I must understand the exact consumption rates, how the "spare battery" swap mechanism works, and where the charging stations (specifically the booster at Violet-3) are located. Gaining full technical details is the first step toward calculating a viable path that preserves enough energy for the Green row.

history.location_text:
Instead of answering Hab pointed to the window opening to the testing pavilion. There were half a dozen of platforms about two meters in diameter each hanging behind the window at a height of almost 20 meters. The distance between them was from 2 to 10 meters. The platforms were white with one coloured stripe along the edge.

- There are five rows of platforms here, each row is marked with a certain colour. The technicians changed the configuration many times already making the facility easier and safer, so I have only general information about its structure: 
- Starting point
- Yellow row - 4 platforms
- Red row - 4 platforms
- Violet row - 5 platforms, plus one battery charger
- Blue row - 4 platforms, the teleport can be used here
- Green row - 3 platforms, the teleport is active here too
- Final point - the testing is over here.

I would advise you to drag your heels here and study the facility's structure first. When you reach the Green or Blue row, you will be able to return to the starting point, charge your batteries and do the testing from the beginning. But note - you can do it just once.

My previous failure was due to running out of energy in the final (Green) row, so calculating the total cost from Start to Finish is the top priority. I have already learned the general layout (Yellow, Red, Violet, Blue, Green), but without the precise mathematical consumption for distance, I cannot optimize the jumps to land on the Violet-3 charger with low energy or use even-numbered swap platforms effectively.

history.location_text:
Depending on the length of the jump, the power consumption will be the following:

2 meters - 4 ergo 
3-4 meters - 5 ergo
5 meters - 7 ergo
6-7 meters - 8 ergo
8 meters - 10 ergo
9-12 meters - 15 ergo

Our technicians promise that 40 ergo will be enough to go through the labyrinth. You are given two batteries  20 ergo each. Only one battery can be active - its power is used for the jump. But you can replace the battery with the help of the special device - there are such samples in the test labyrinth.

history.location_text:
- In the first place, you can replace the active battery with the spare one  on every platform with an even number  and use it for jumping.
Secondly, there is a charger installed on the central platform of the Violet row  - it adds 12 ergo to the active battery automatically.
Thirdly, there is an accelerator on the first platform  of some row, I can't remember now which one. It will transfer you onto the first platform of the next sector just for 1 ergo. 
And of course, we will provide you with a portable teleport, which will help you to return to the starting point where you will be able to charge the both batteries and start from the beginning. But it's disposable and can be used only on the platforms of the Blue and Green rows!

history.llm_response:
REASONING: I have now gathered all critical technical data: the consumption rates (4-15 ergo), the specific locations of mechanical aids (even-numbered platforms for battery swaps, the +12 ergo charger at Violet-3, and the existence of a high-efficiency accelerator on a Row-1 platform), and the one-time teleport function from the Blue/Green rows. 

Based on my previous failure, the strategy is as follows:
1. Reach Violet-3 with the lowest possible active battery energy to maximize the benefit of the +12 ergo charger (without dropping to 0).
2. Utilize even-numbered platforms to cycle the spare battery, ensuring both batteries contribute to the journey.
3. Locate the accelerator (likely Green-1 or Blue-1) to preserve energy for the final jump.
4. Avoid Violet-5 as it was previously identified as a dead end.

I have all the necessary information to begin the test.

history.location_text:
The professor wished you good luck and blessed you. Then he took you to the test pavilion.
- Note that the battery replacement devices are installed on the even platforms of each sector. Here is a portable teleport adjusted to return back here. You can use it only once - while passing the labyrinth' last two rows. The emergency return button means that you cancel the testing of just can't complete it. And in case of any accidents - well, you understand what I mean, mind your language and don't dirty the floor - our young ladies assisting in the lab have such a weak stomach.

You went up the stairs to the starting point. Meanwhile the professor and a dozen of his associates were making bets what platform you will fall from. 
"Snooks, lab rats", - you got furious and came to the edge. It is high! Round 20 meters, so the fall will be short but very painful. Well, you must jump. Which sector will you choose?
params: You are at the starting point
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I need to cross the Yellow row efficiently while preparing for the Red and Violet rows. 
- Yellow-1 costs 10 ergo (8m). It is an odd platform, so no battery swap.
- Yellow-2 costs 10 ergo (8m). It is an even platform, allowing a battery swap.
- Yellow-3 costs 7 ergo (5m). It is an odd platform.
- Yellow-4 costs 8 ergo (6m). It is an even platform.

My goal is to reach Violet-3 with low energy to maximize the +12 ergo boost. Starting at Yellow-3 is the most energy-efficient entry (only 7 ergo), leaving me with 13 ergo in the active battery for the next jump. This conservation is key to reaching the later stages of the labyrinth where energy becomes scarce.

history.location_text: You landed softly onto the platform, which didn't even vibrate. There were a lot of footprints of all possible shapes and sizes - from sneakers to huge bare Maloq heels.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I am currently on Yellow-3 with 13 ergo. Jumping to Red-4 (6 meters) costs 8 ergo. This would leave me on an even-numbered platform (Red-4) with 5 ergo in Battery #1. Landing on an even platform is strategic because it allows me to swap to Battery #2 (20 ergo) for the transition into the Violet row. This maximizes my total available energy and moves me closer to the Violet-3 charger while keeping Battery #2 fresh for the more expensive jumps ahead. Jumping within the Yellow row now would be a waste of energy.

history.location_text:
A soft fall with a roll and a roar of a parturient gobzaurus - you all but fell off the platform that turned out to be surprisingly slippery. You could hardly hold up and saw that the platform had a bad list.

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I am currently on Red-4, an even platform. My active battery (#1) has only 5 ergo remaining, while my spare battery (#2) is full at 20 ergo. To reach the Violet-3 charger or cross the Violet row safely, I need more than 5 ergo. Since I can only swap batteries on even platforms, this is a critical opportunity to switch to the fresh battery. By switching now, I will have 20 ergo available for the jump into the Violet row, ensuring I don't get stranded on an odd platform with insufficient energy.

As noted in my previous attempt reflection, Violet-5 is a dead end with no forward exits to the Blue row, making it a waste of energy. Therefore, I will jump to Violet-4. A jump from Red-4 to Violet-4 (3 meters) costs 5 ergo. This will leave me on Violet-4 with 15 ergo, which is an even-numbered platform, allowing me another battery swap if needed before moving to the central charger at Violet-3.

history.location_text:
The platform was flying at you. You tried to remember some prayers but only nasty stories and recipes of the Maloq cuisine came to your mind. You were lucky though and escaped just with fright and injured manhood - fortunately, no self-maiming.

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I am on Violet-4 with 15 ergo in the active battery (#2). My objective is to land on Violet-3 to utilize the battery charger, which adds 12 ergo. The jump to Violet-3 is 6 meters, costing 8 ergo. If I jump now, I will arrive at Violet-3 with 7 ergo (15 - 8), and the charger will boost me to 19 ergo. This is an excellent energy level for the upcoming Blue and Green rows. I will not replace the battery here because Battery #2 currently has much more energy (15) than Battery #1 (5), and I want to maximize the +12 ergo boost on the active battery. I am avoiding Violet-5 as it was previously identified as a dead end.

ACTION: 2

history.location_text:
Hardly had you landed onto the platform, an automated voice said:
"Active battery, current charge - 7 ergo. Boost charging function is active. Boost charging complete. Active battery, current charge - 19 ergo"

"Heh, I wish my spaceship had such a battery", - you thought enviously.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I have successfully reached Violet-3 and received the +12 ergo boost, bringing Battery #2 to 19 ergo. My goal now is to cross the Blue row and enter the Green row with as much energy as possible. Looking at the options:
- Blue-2 (5m) costs 7 ergo. This is an even platform (battery swap available). 19 - 7 = 12 ergo.
- Blue-3 (2m) costs 4 ergo. This is an odd platform. 19 - 4 = 15 ergo.
- Blue-4 (5m) costs 7 ergo. This is an even platform (battery swap available). 19 - 7 = 12 ergo.

In my previous failure, I struggled in the Green row because of low energy. While Blue-3 is the cheapest jump, landing on an even platform like Blue-2 or Blue-4 is strategically superior. Why? Because on an even platform, I can swap to Battery #1 (currently 5 ergo), use it for a jump to the Green row, and then swap back to a near-full Battery #2 on an even Green platform. However, since entering the Green row is the goal, I will take the shortest path to an even platform to keep options open. Blue-2 is a solid choice.

ACTION: 1

history.location_text:
After you slammed on the platform, you realised what problems make the life of grasshoppers, fleas and jumpawaiians so hard and short. They pull such stunts one hundred times per day.

The portable teleport started peeping on your belt. That meant it was active. It will help you to return to the starting point to charge the batteries and  - good luck again!
There is a battery replacement device here too.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I am on Blue-2 with 12 ergo in Battery #2 and 5 ergo in Battery #1. In my previous failure, reaching the Green row with low energy was my downfall. I have two paths forward:
1. Jump to Green-1 (4 meters) for 5 ergo, leaving 7 ergo in Battery #2. Green-1 is an odd platform, so no more swaps there.
2. Jump to Green-2 (8 meters) for 10 ergo, leaving 2 ergo in Battery #2. However, Green-2 is an EVEN platform, which would allow me to swap to Battery #1. But Battery #1 only has 5 ergo, which isn't enough to reach the finish.

Recall from Step 6: "there is an accelerator on the first platform of some row... It will transfer you onto the first platform of the next sector just for 1 ergo." 
If I jump to Green-1, I will likely find this accelerator to reach the Final Point for only 1 ergo. 
Jump to Green-1 (5 ergo) + Accelerator (1 ergo) = 6 ergo total cost. I currently have 12 ergo. This is a very safe margin. I will not use the teleport yet, as I have sufficient energy to explore the accelerator lead.

history.location_text: You admired your masterpiece with all the pride sailing up to the ceiling. This time it was not just a swearword that you managed to scratch but a whole poem written by your drunken friend Harry long ago. Even Maloq pirates of the blackest dye redden with embarrassment when they hear it. You were too modest to sign your name in the end and just wrote: "Corsair Santa Clause. Happy New Year, freaks!"
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I have reached Green-1 with 7 ergo in the active battery. According to the technical briefing in Step 6, there is an accelerator on the first platform of one of the rows that allows travel to the next sector for only 1 ergo. My previous notes and the logic of the quest suggest that the "next sector" from the Green row is the Final Point. If the accelerator is active on Green-1, I should see an option to reach the finish or use the device. However, the current choices only show the teleport, the internal jump to Green-2, or the emergency button.

Looking at the jump distances: Green-1 to Green-2 is 4 meters (5 ergo). If I move to Green-2 (an even platform), I will be left with 2 ergo. On Green-2, I can swap to Battery #1, which has 5 ergo. This would give me just enough to make a final jump.

Wait, I should check if the accelerator triggers automatically or if I've missed a row-1 platform earlier. If I use the teleport now, I return to the start with fully charged batteries (20/20) and the knowledge of the exact path. Given I only have 7 ergo and 5 ergo left, and the final jump distance is unknown but likely costs at least 4-5 ergo, using the teleport is the safest professional choice to ensure a win, as I only get one chance to use it. It effectively doubles my total energy for the final run.

history.location_text:
You transferred to the starting point. The professor ran to you and hooked up the charger to the batteries:
- So, did you manage to study the labyrinth well enough? Note, you have no more chances to return. And we are pressed for time - we need to format the report, attach it to the application form, register and queue to the acceptance committee. Hurry up, please. You are not the only one after 65535 credits. Honestly, I don't cherish high hopes that you will be a success. The technicians must have done something wrong again reconfiguring the facility. Though they swear that the labyrinth is passable...

You reassured the scholar that you would manage it by all means and got ready for the first jump...
params: You are at the starting point
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I have used my one-time teleport to return to the start with two fully charged batteries (20/20). Based on my previous scouting, I know the following: 
1. Violet-3 contains a charger that adds 12 ergo. To maximize this, I should arrive there with enough energy to make the jump but low enough to not waste the +12 boost (max capacity is 20).
2. Even-numbered platforms allow battery swaps.
3. Violet-5 is a dead end.

My strategy for this final run:
- Jump to Yellow-3 (5m, 7 ergo). Active (B1): 13, Spare (B2): 20.
- Jump to Yellow-4 (2m, 4 ergo). Active (B1): 9, Spare (B2): 20.
- On Yellow-4, swap to B2. Active (B2): 20, Spare (B1): 9.
- Jump to Red-4 (from scouted experience, cost is manageable). 
- Eventually reach Violet-3 with B2 low enough to receive the +12 boost.
By starting with Yellow-3, I follow the most efficient path discovered in the previous steps.

ACTION: 3
history.reasoning:
I have used my one-time teleport to return to the start with two fully charged batteries (20/20). Based on my previous scouting, I know the following: 
1. Violet-3 contains a charger that adds 12 ergo. To maximize this, I should arrive there with enough energy to make the jump but low enough to not waste the +12 boost (max capacity is 20).
2. Even-numbered platforms allow battery swaps.
3. Violet-5 is a dead end.

My strategy for this final run:
- Jump to Yellow-3 (5m, 7 ergo). Active (B1): 13, Spare (B2): 20.
- Jump to Yellow-4 (2m, 4 ergo). Active (B1): 9, Spare (B2): 20.
- On Yellow-4, swap to B2. Active (B2): 20, Spare (B1): 9.
- Jump to Red-4 (from scouted experience, cost is manageable). 
- Eventually reach Violet-3 with B2 low enough to receive the +12 boost.
By starting with Yellow-3, I follow the most efficient path discovered in the previous steps.

history.location_text:
There were a lot of footprints of all possible shapes and sizes on the platform - from sneakers to huge bare Maloq heels.
"I am no worse" - you thought and decided to put yourself on record. After many fruitless and rather painful attempts to imprint your foot on the platform, you just used your blaster to poker a 58-64-size footprint with your name - Ranger - inside and were satisfied.
history.llm_response:

Landing on Yellow-4 is strategic because it is an even-numbered platform, which allows me to swap my active battery for the fresh spare battery (#2, 20 ergo). This will leave me at the end of the first row with 20 ergo in my active battery and 9 ergo remaining in my spare, putting me in a much stronger position for the Red and Violet rows compared to previous attempts.

history.llm_response:
REASONING: I am on Red-4 with 13 ergo in Battery #2. My target is the Violet-3 charger (+12 ergo). To reach it, I must first enter the Violet row. Jumping to Violet-4 (3 meters) costs 5 ergo, which will leave me with 8 ergo. From Violet-4, the jump to Violet-3 is 6 meters (8 ergo). This is mathematically perfect: landing on Violet-3 with 0 ergo (or near 0) and immediately receiving the +12 boost to reach 12 ergo. If I switched to Battery #1 now (9 ergo), I would reach Violet-4 with 4 ergo, which is not enough to make the 8 ergo jump to Violet-3. Therefore, staying with Battery #2 is the only way to reach the charger. I will continue to avoid Violet-5 as it is a dead end.

The platform was flying at you. You tried to remember some prayers but only nasty stories and recipes of the Maloq cuisine came to your mind. You were lucky though and escaped just with fright and injured manhood - fortunately, no self-maiming.

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I am currently on Violet-4 with 8 ergo in my active battery (#2). My priority is to land on Violet-3 to receive the +12 ergo boost from the charger. The jump from Violet-4 to Violet-3 is 6 meters, which costs exactly 8 ergo. This will leave the active battery at 0 ergo, but the charger triggers "on landing," which will bring the battery up to 12 ergo. If I were to switch to Battery #1 (9 ergo) now, I would arrive at Violet-3 with 1 ergo (total 13 after boost), which is roughly the same outcome. However, Battery #2 is already active, and this path is efficient. I am avoiding Violet-5 as previous scouting confirmed it is a dead end with no exits to the Blue row. After reaching Violet-3 and getting the boost, I will have sufficient energy to reach the Blue and Green sectors.

history.location_text:
Hardly had you landed onto the platform, an automated voice said:
"Active battery, current charge - 0 ergo. Boost charging function is active. Boost charging complete. Active battery, current charge - 12 ergo"

"Heh, I wish my spaceship had such a battery", - you thought enviously.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I am on Violet-3 with 12 ergo in Battery #2 and 9 ergo in Battery #1. To maximize my chances of reaching the finish, I need to land on even platforms to maintain the ability to swap to my spare battery. 

Looking at the options:
- Blue-2 (5m) costs 7 ergo. This is an even platform (allows battery swap). 12 - 7 = 5 ergo remaining.
- Blue-3 (2m) costs 4 ergo. This is an odd platform. 12 - 4 = 8 ergo remaining.
- Blue-4 (5m) costs 7 ergo. This is an even platform. 12 - 7 = 5 ergo remaining.

Blue-2 is the best strategic choice because it is even. If I land there with 5 ergo in Battery #2, I can swap to Battery #1 which has 9 ergo. This gives me a much higher total energy (9 ergo) to make the jump from Blue into the Green row. If I went to Blue-3, I'd have 8 ergo but no way to access the 9 ergo in my spare battery, potentially stranding me if the next jump is expensive.

history.location_text:
If your memory serves you well, last time you thought about grasshoppers' fate right on this place. Grasshoppers are nothing compared to you! They don't have to simultaneously gauge the difference in the cost of luxury goods on Aldeeb and Venus.  Try to explain to some Rachekhan's offspring that the only cargo for sale in your hold are beam weapons and Maloq coffins and you would be happy to share them in this particular order. Lucky insects - they continually eat and crap everywhere. Nothing else!.

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: I am on Blue-2 with only 5 ergo in my active battery (#2). My spare battery (#1) currently has 9 ergo. Since I am on an even-numbered platform, I must use this opportunity to swap to the fuller battery. The Jump to the Green row (Green-1) costs 5 ergo. If I don't swap, I would arrive at Green-1 with 0 ergo and be unable to utilize the accelerator or make the final jump. By swapping now, I will land on Green-1 with 4 ergo (9 - 5) and still have a backup battery (though nearly empty at 5 ergo, it might be swappable if I reach an even Green platform). Most importantly, having 4 ergo on Green-1 is essential to trigger the accelerator to the final sector.

failure_reflection: REASONING: The failure occurred at the transition from Blue to Green. I reached Blue-2 with 9 ergo, but jumping to Green-1 (5 ergo) left me with only 4 ergo. My strategy relied on the "accelerator" on the first platform of a sector (Green-1) to reach the final sector for 1 ergo. However, I reached Green-1 with 4 ergo and the mission failed, likely because 4 ergo was insufficient for the final jump sequence or I miscalculated the cost of the exit. STRATEGIC MISTAKES: 1. I entered the final stretch with too little energy (9 ergo total) by not managing the Violet-3 charger more effectively. 2. I relied on an assumption about the "accelerator" location without having sufficient surplus energy to compensate if it required more than 4 ergo to reach the exit from Green-1. OPTIMAL PATH DATA: - Violet-3 (+12 ergo) is essential. - Even platforms allow battery swaps; utilize these to combine the highest remaining charges. - The path Yellow-3 -> Yellow-4 -> Red-4 -> Violet-4 -> Violet-3 is viable but requires higher entry energy to ensure the Blue/Green sector finish. NEXT TIME: Arrive at Violet-3 with a higher total energy reserve (better management of Battery #1) and try...
